Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Next, put a small bandage soaked with olive oil between them to prevent friction and separate the fingers gently in order to make sure that they are properly aligned according to what is required.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly if the connection is made with one finger and a palm, then dry that connection afterwards according to what has been prepared and bring them into shape of their members.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 On cutting off the skin
Caput XCII.	 Head XVI
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Veins are often filled with melancholy fluids that accumulate in several parts of the body; and most frequently they appear on the face (especially on the cheeks) but can also be found on the hands: especially on the ears of those who work or labor, as well as the ones who bring things to others.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore let you administer a strong purging from black bile occasionally in order to get rid of that heaviness.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Afterwards, take out the base of the patient's vein from the body using tweezers.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 The cure for them is done in two different ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 The first method is to let the vein dry and become hard, after which it will be possible to cut away any excess flesh that might remain; the second method is to drain off black blood from them using a knife.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 The other way is to take out the vein completely and let it dry on its own.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The cut for them has two methods: either you can open up their skin in order to remove any excess flesh that might remain, or you can use a knife to cut away the vein.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 First squeeze them gently with warm water until the thick and foul blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Next, take their feet and gently lift up one of them to the upper portion of their thigh; then hold it in place with a bandage from below down to just above the knee.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Afterwards let you dry off that part either by one cut or two cuts or three cuts made wide open.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Afterwards let you remove the blood from your hand down to its top by squeezing it gently; afterwards lift up their leg and take out the blood from above downwards on them first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 After removing the skin and below it goes: until a certain quantity of blood is reached that you can endure with safety, and as much endurance as the virtue of the patient allows.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Follow the vein until he has been held back by his food and drink causing night-time (choleric) illness. And then repeat evacuation and phlebotomy when the vein is complete to prevent this weakness from occurring.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 This method of removal can be done in that manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 If the patient has many hairs on his chest (axilla), shave them first
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 After that introduce him into the bath; either shave him with warm water or wrap him in a hot towel until he rouses up (becomes conscious), and the veins will be stirred. Or you may exercise vigorously if there is no present bath to heat the member.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 After that remove the skin along the vein's length or shave him at his knee and ankle.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then remove the skin with the fingers, and scrape away every part until you see him (the patient) again; this is to prevent a recurrence of night-time illness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 After that make him sit up on his back with the skin removed and the bed sheet over him as if it were a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 After that introduce under the lamp (Radium) until he is completely free of skin; hold him with your fingers and gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 And after that remove another area along its length with three digits.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then scrape away the upper part of the skin until you see him again.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 After that make her sit up on her back with the skin removed and the bed sheet over her as before; hold her gently with your fingers just like you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 And after that remove another area or more if necessary.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then remove the last area from his ankle.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 And after that take her to an area which is above her (i.e., a higher level).
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 Cut it out from a section that is above or to one of higher sections and when you have cut all around, then strike her.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 If you cannot remove it yourself and need assistance, then introduce the double file gently with both hands, bind her, and remove her in that way; or introduce a smaller instrument underneath (a "Radium"), tie it around, and remove them together: either way, place your hand on all parts of her to make sure she is removed.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And let this happen.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 If it fails, you will find that removing her is very difficult and painful.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you have completely removed her: then place a cloth soaked with wine and olive oil over the area where she has been to soak up any remaining blood or fluids; if necessary use olive oil only, and take care of it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If the wine has been contracted and you are holding a piece of cloth soaked with its flow that fits into her, but it is not as we described according to rectitude: then let him find a way to place it on all parts of her torturousness (the wound) and apply the solutions for these wounds.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 After that tie her up with cords until you have completely removed her; and also ensure there is no cut or wound in the section where she was located, unless it is necessary to use something else; for this will be very difficult for you to remove her after all.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 So act prudently.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 Form of the wounds being healed by wine.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 Shape of cutting off the eye, and you are done.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It is not as smooth and fine as the others; it is also acute in its extremity so that she did not need to be removed yet; but it is very broad and flexible, being soft when necessary, so excessive force was needed for her removal, like we said before.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 Removal of the veins on the leg
Caput XCIII.	 The end of the book.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This is a translation from an Arabic text on surgery by Albucasis and it means: The veins are generated in the limbs with warm blood, like those of Alizegi, as well as the earth of the Arabs and the arid lands, with hot blood, the tender shrubs; that is, none of them generate herbs or trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 Perhaps they are generated in other parts of the body besides limbs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 The generation of that is due to the decay which happens under the skin, just like how snakes and lice enter into the bodies of people, but in turn also they cause generations within the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 The mark of the beginning of this vein is that it causes inflammation on the inflamed limb.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then it goes away from the place.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then this vein leaves its location as if to be a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When therefore this extremity of the vein appears from it then is required to come up and go over on that very limb as if it were a rope, whose length is equal to two drachmas two nadirs; and let him drop down to two drachmas two nadirs: and let him hold his breath until he drops the suspended weight from the limb.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 When therefore a certain amount of that vein is drawn out to the outside then let him pull it down with all his strength into the weight; and let him release what he has pulled down.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If however the vein is prolonged much then it shall cut off a certain portion of its own length and pull down the remainder
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut off before he has drawn out all of that vein.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 Since it is cut off then retracts and goes into the flesh; and makes to sting a point of the arm, and causes decay in that place, and an ulcer forms.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore it is required that he be pulled out slowly and carefully so as to leave the last part of its own length, until after being drawn all at once from its last end; and nothing remains within or on that vein in the body: and therefore this very vein will be found among certain men who are in length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And a finger was brought to me because it had been cut off from its hand.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If your finger is cut off at the time of your medication: then introduce a remedy into its hole and perforate it with long force until all that is within her has been extracted from the material, after which you must administer the cure for the corruption in place along with remedies on specific days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Therefore take care of your finger's healing immediately
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it is seen at the incision of the foot (or ankle), or itself on the foot, for openings are made to it often, and from all these openings its course goes out
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore take care of this one as we said in the foot's incision, and with what has been removed from it
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 In order to cure a bite by worms placed on you: and there is called Aegiruddy-buggy
Caput XCIIII.	 The head XIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 The name Aegiruddy-buggy is given to it at our place because many worms have bitten into it and one has been born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 It is introduced into the entire body, rising and falling; and it is shown to those walking by him from member to member until its fall has occurred wherever or whenever it falls on you and it is removed.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 Its generation comes out of corrupt matter mixed with various humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 Just like worms and snakes are cut off from the belly: so too, lice and scabies are removed from within the body.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 Fear arises out of its badness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when he introduced himself into the body and is extracted to the head and place, then perhaps it opens up in him and is removed, and destroys the eye; and many are destroyed from that
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 With so you take care of him, and remove him, then it is not possible for this unless he appears to the walking by him senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 "Therefore, in order that you may draw what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then dry the above mentioned thing (the ligature), and extract from it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If it penetrates into the flesh, but not your hand; then place on top of a location with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 As for what you are more afraid of, that is his corruption, which has blinded him, just as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If then you see it already penetrating towards the eye or near to it, then draw a good strong ligature below it
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then dry above mentioned thing (the ligature), and extract from it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 It is necessary that the weakened body of the man should be made fresh with the help of medicines, lest bad smells come out through the pores of his body.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let him eat from foods which cause decay.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 Of the cutting above the disease called Nakir.
Caput XCV.	 Hundred and fifty-first part of the work (?).
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This disease is called Nakir in our land; and there is pain which happened to some parts; then it is changed from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I also saw this thing already (the ligature), as you have said.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I am called to a weak woman in some old age.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 He loses his arm and sees swelling of the veins in the new branches of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after some time passed, I saw a swelling to come with the fire as it comes from veins; and ascending towards his upper arm location which can be; so that he is like gold flowing when it runs from one place to another.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 Therefore the pain went away at this location, and was fixed on his shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 After some time passed, he began to flow again through the remaining body; until it flows into another limb.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Therefore I told him because everything was happening in his entire body as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 "I am making an incision in order to separate its member from another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 "And I, being ignorant of that particular method before this lesson, saw it thus with my eyes.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 "However many have learned the art of separating one member from another; but I saw it not as you did with him, when you showed me on a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 "I do not think this to be true unless I see that one member is extracted from another by those who are skilled in the art of removing dry flesh; hence it appears to me the delight of such a transformation.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 "It is necessary that this method does not appear as delightful to those who are not skilled or have no feeling for the art of removing dry flesh; and so it may be seen.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 "Now that you are the master of this art and have felt the pain, perhaps it will be seen by your eye as we have shown; then tie it above him with a knot and beneath him too; dry over it and away it goes; and leave the cut place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 "If you do not see it with your eyes then cure it as with the removal of flesh, and with what he expelled sweetness; or bind them up to remove them quickly; and cauterize the place.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 "On the art of removing veins
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter 66
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Veins are removed differently according to their nature and the place where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 Their difference is this; for some of them have large cusps and are rough or hairy while others have small ones that are smooth or hairless.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And there are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And there are veins that come from the mouth.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And some of them are from stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 The veins removed according to the members in which they fall is done according to two different ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 Or the main veins are removed from the principal members such as the brain and heart and liver and lungs and kidneys and intestines and urinary passages; and similarly those.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When a member of the body has fallen to you and it is clear that death is at hand, I am about to tell you what signs must be taken away from there, so you can take out its arrow, for death follows him where he lies, in many positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these signs are bad and the arrow is not withdrawn from deep within a member, then withdraw it, and look after the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 When the arrow falls into the brain and penetrates deeply, it is said: Because these things happen to him as a result of falling from that height [i.e., from above]: blindness, and turning blind to others; vertigo in his head, and redness in his eyes; swelling up in his tongue, and spasming in his head, and disturbance in his mind, and death by cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And perhaps [therefore] the blood may come from the nostrils or the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 Perhaps it is withdrawn and destroyed speech.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And because of the white dew from the hollows [of his body] he may lose consciousness.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And as a result of this, similar to that which occurs in the limbs, it is said: He exits by a loss of bodily fluid.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If you see these signs then stay away from the care and withdraw the arrow if it is not withdrawn already.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The arrow signs when it falls into the heart are as follows: It is said that this one was near the left nipple and felt as if it were fixed deeply to a hard object but not to a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps the arrow movement is similar to that of a pulse and its course follows through the blood with blackness [i.e., death].
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 It also follows these things: it causes frost in the extremities, cold sweat, and syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Therefore, you know that death is near but far off [i.e., imminent].
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 The arrow sign when it was shot into the lung is as follows: It causes death by blood spurting from the wound and the veins collapse, with falling to the ground; and the color of the body changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 When a large vein is cut, its source and target are sought after for air's coldness
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If a vein is cut off from its origin (the heart), then the end of that vein would be towards the back, causing severe pain and great suffering throughout all the limbs.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 If a vein is cut off from its origin (the heart) into the stomach, then the food would be digested as if it were poison
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 If a vein is cut off from its origin (the heart) into the lungs, then it would bring out something bad and putrid from the veins or abdomen, having been disrupted.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 There was no hope of his cure through its collection nor through extraction of the vein.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If a vein is cut off from its origin (the heart) into the bladder and it is collected urine out of her, then something bad would come out to the outside causing severe pain. That person would be mortal at that time.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The members are healed like a face; the collar and jaw also, and the spatula and support for the tongue, and the spine of the neck, and the ribs (costae), and the thighs (crus) heal themselves from the limbs in different positions when they did not get any blood vessel.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 I tell you what I heard about those veins so that you may understand through it regarding your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 Because one of the eyes was cut off from a vein to his nose and eye socket.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore, I extracted it on the other side under his ear, and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye at all.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 I also extracted another vein from the Judean on his ear lobe where it had been cut off under the lower eyelid of him and that vein was hidden and not reached through it but only a small part of its end towards his own wood. It was a large vein from the vein arc of the Turks, with a steel-like bend, in which no ears were
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 The eye of Jhoor is healthy and not a cause for harm.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 He extracted an arrow from the flesh of a Christian
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 The arrow was Arab and it could see ears (it's unclear what this means).
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 He therefore placed her between two guides, and she sank into his flesh.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 I am now skilled with him, until he extracted her; then the Christian was healthy.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 He extracted another arrow that had fallen into his flesh and we pondered about it because of its death.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After 30 days had passed him and nothing was changed on top of him except for something from his disposition, I placed her above the arrow; I used my skill with her, and extracted her; then he became healthy, but not a cause for harm to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 I saw the man who shot the arrow into his back and it was closed over her.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After 7 years had passed she exited from the root of the thigh of him.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 I saw a woman who shot the arrow into her flesh and it was closed over her; she remained inside of her until the arrow did not change from his dispositions or the woman did not get harmed by any of his natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 I saw another man who shot the arrow into his face and it was closed over; she remained inside of him until he did not get a lot of pain, like that many others.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 He extracted an arrow from the hand of the King that had fallen into his nasal cavity and it was declining toward the right side; she was hidden completely.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 I am now skilled at his care after the arrow incident until 3 days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 The arrow wound was closed tightly.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 I asked him with a gentle touch and he did not feel her; himself also felt the pain and the discomfort from his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 I pierced it with a point at its extreme tip
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I extracted it from the place where its virtue had been attracted by a bandage and digested. By my confidence that this place would revert to me, and there appeared to me an image of the arrowhead so that I could grasp it onto the arrow. And no accident occurred at the place where the arrowhead was placed.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I assiduously worked with the bandage over several days: and no accident occurred; it was consolidated into an injury temporarily; and he remained weak due to its extraction from his space of days until one day he became sensitive to the arrowhead when inserted into his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 He told me that story.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I placed the bandage on that injury acutely corrosive over several days until it was opened; and when I tried to grasp it with my fingers, I felt its subtle extreme tip that clung onto a stick.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 After that I added to the opened wound with a sharp bandage; until it appeared before us clearly its tip of the arrowhead, and remained in my space for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 After the wound was enlarged and I could insert my finger into it; grasp it; but it would not obey me to leave: thus I did continue with subtlety, and attempt to grasp her with the methods of beginners until one day when I made a more forceful effort using my fingers as though they were stronger than hers at the end of the chapter, she was then extracted.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 After that, I restored the wound
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 But the physicians say cartilage of the nose cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore returned to that wound and it was consolidated back into its place; he became healthy with an integral body without anything happening to him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I say to you the quality of extracting arrows some day; so that you put it in regulation and meaning over what was not mentioned.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Since the parts of this art and their distinctiveness are not comprehended with narration; nor was it comprehended by that liber [book], or wise craftsman compares to little in excess: and when he is present, above what is absent from him; and a new operation occurred along with a new instrument among the descent of things extraneous to this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 "Therefore I conclude that arrows are not shot from the parts of the body to which they are attached except in two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 "Or through an attraction caused by a place where it had entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or otherwise another part's, the first being reversed.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 "The one which enters where it had entered either proceeds from that place, or is an arrow shot at a dead spot, drawing towards itself and shooting out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 "If it does not move towards its exit when it fell there, then you have to remove it a few days later until the body that is around him putrefies, and this attraction will be removed from him, but his exiting.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 "And similarly if it is drawn into bone and does not proceed towards its exit for you, then remove her also a few days later, and repeat the same with attraction and movement every day until she shoots out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 "If it does not move towards its exit after a day, then you have to remove the arrows from all around them on that bone until they are increased.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 "Then draw her out and remove her.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 "If an arrow is fixed to the skull bone and has gone through one ventricle of the brain, as I mentioned earlier, then you should abstain from drawing arrows for him, and remove her until he becomes equal after another day.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 "If an arrow penetrates into it [the carotid artery], the death of that person is not prolonged anymore.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 "If the arrow is not fixed just to the bones of his body and did not penetrate until it got into the carotid artery, then he was sick for a while but nothing like that happened to him from those accidents [injuries], then you have to think about drawing arrows and removing her.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 "If it is fixed to the exit point and does not proceed towards your attraction [to attract him], then you should administer a terebela around those arrows just as I mentioned earlier, like this, until you cure the place.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow has already been shot through the body and is hidden from view by its own force or that of another object, then it should be grasped with one's hand while pulling
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel the arrow, then grasp it using certain instruments that are used to extract or remove it from its path
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you are unable to grasp the arrow because of its strength or because it is too deeply embedded in a wound, then search for an instrument that can make it possible to extract the arrow from its path and remove it from the wound's depth
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If you have ears that hold it fast, then free the limb from these around all parts with every possible means to do so, and if the mind is unable to release the flesh by tearing or bending its ears, until you succeed in removing this by any means possible to find.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And when you are administering the extraction of an arrow at any place, then use your hand's force with fingers to all parts until you succeed in removing it: and lastly with the most subtle subtlety so that the arrow won't be broken and makes it difficult for you to grasp it and extract it.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you are unable to remove the arrow immediately but instead release it for a certain number of days until its decomposition occurs around where it is embedded.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Next time you come across this arrow, then use what we mentioned from the chapter on maintenance and watch for your strength to be maintained by not cutting through flesh or bone.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer the mind in every way possible for you to extract an arrow from it: and let this be done with ease, tranquility, delay or firmness as we have taught you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when grasping the arrow, its weakness should be according to shape as it was at the time of shooting.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because this has been explained more clearly
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If you are unable to do what we have taught you in the chapter on maintenance, then administer with figures what is possible for you.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 A needle that is drawn from the opposite side, or has proceeded from it to something on the outside; or causes deformation of the arrow due to it passing through a nearby skin part and thereby becomes prominent; so therefore cut off this excess above it, and then proceed according to how much space there is for cutting with the fingers.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw (the needle) out of her thus easily by exiting from within her.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If you want to grasp it by bone, then bend your hand according to its roundness until you have inserted the arrow into the bone and it has been amplified for yourself; thereafter draw out that same one [the needle].
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not so, release her after a certain number of days until she returns to you again.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the wood is in there [the arrow], then pull (her) with it [the wood].
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 If the wood has perished and you wish to administer the thrust: then introduce into her an instrument with a concavity so that it may be inserted through its concavity, into the arrow shaft; thereafter pull (her) along with him [the wood].
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If the arrow is concave: then pull her along with an instrument entering through that same one.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 The arrow pierces (her) by this way [that is, she is pulled out].
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow has been poisoned, then you must, so as to cut through the entire piece of meat that it is located in; if possible for you [that is, if you have the necessary tool].
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then take care of her with respect to what will be necessary for this thing [that is, perform first aid on her].
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the arrow falls into the breast [heart], or the belly, or the groin, or the thigh; and is close to that which you take hold of when attempting to draw her out: it is possible for you to cut off above her with a knife (or to tear), so as to remove her.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 If you are able, then take care of the wound and see that it is healed [that is, bandage the wound].
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 This is the shape of a snare (trap) from which hooks are drawn out by means of an arrow
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The hands and feet resemble claws that grasp iron rods when they are held over arrows but do not let go of them when the arrows pass through.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And many forms arise from them, great and small, according to the amount of arrows and their power, and in their variety; for they grasp with varying tightness as the arrows pass through them.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 Shape of the extractor hook.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 Shape of the snare (trap) is closed, ready to trap a creature that can't escape when it hits the arrow shaft.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the shape of the snare (trap) like a hoop to hold it when entering and guiding through with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The shape of the snare (trap) is like a bird's claw to hold it when entering and guide through with it, so that its entrance into the arrow shaft occurs smoothly and pushes it on.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 On phlebotomy of veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter 70 of [book].
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 Veins which are customarily introduced into the body number thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 Among which veins at the head there are six ten, two behind ears called herbae, two behind eyes called aspicientes, and one on each side above the nose; and one in the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two guides (veins) which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins which are in the upper lip of each side of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins which are in the lower lip of each side of the mouth.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 These are called algecherich veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins which are under the tongue on each side.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 Veins which are introduced into arms there are five for every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 The left cephalic vein is located on the right side of the head; and named by the Latin word for head (capitis).
Et Fusca.	 "And there is blood.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 It is flesh; it is composed of a part from the base of the temple and another from the skull's branch. And you should call this by its proper name 'the body'.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 It is flesh; it is placed on the lower part of the home. And it is also called 'Titillarum'.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 Call this by its proper name, 'the belly'.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 It is flesh; it is placed above the fire. And that from which blood flows, and that on which the hand appears when pressed, are they.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 The navel; there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 In the thigh and in the calf, three of them exist.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 It is flesh; it is placed under the thumb's curve from the lower side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 The second one is called 'Saphena', and its place is at the back of the calf, near the ankle.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 There is another one; it's name is 'Nesse'. And its place is on the back of the calf, at the ankle.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 The other thigh also has three branches like them.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 About the flow of blood from two veins after the elbow.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 About two veins that flow blood after the elbow; it is a remedy for catarrh of old times, and against hemorrhoid disease, it makes the head ulcer bad.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 The quality of their flow is according to what they carry.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 It should be applied with a good cloth on the head; and it should be pressed against its veins at their place to stop them.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then the patient puts his neck straight up with a stick, so that two of them appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 The places where they are located after the elbow, on both sides of the head, are depressed.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Ask them with your finger; and when you feel their pulse under it, apply a signet ring there with a hot iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 After taking hold of a syringe and drawing out its contents, there is the person known as Incidents
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 After introducing this into a vein through a needle and connecting it to the blood vessels, after the injection has taken place.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 After placing your hand on top of it and piercing through with a needle at the point of entry (into the vein).
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 The length of the incision depends on the number of fingers involved in piercing it through or around it; make an incision to let out as much blood as possible.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 After wrapping this with bandages and removing them, after the wound has been bandaged up.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And also remember at the beginning of a book to make an incision (of the veins) and burn those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Of two arteries in the time it takes for them
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The two arteries that are pierced by the injection of blood take twice as long; first, to bleed slowly and then to flow quickly, until both fluids have been emptied from them into the eyes (of the person piercing or administering).
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 The quality of the injection is according as you narrow your opening for it.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 A person who has been weakened should bandage their arm much so that two veins will be visible to the appearance; and it is likely for them to beat a pulse under your finger when you touch them.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then, with burning coals
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 After placing the finger on top of it and piercing through with a needle at the point of entry (into the vein), after removing that from above, you will have introduced another one into the same vein.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 Pierce this one as you did with the two others; make it flow out of blood according to how much is needed for your needs.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 After wrapping around a weak vein and placing your finger on top of it during one hour
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 After placing the bandage over this one tightly with strong constriction and removing them, after the wound has been bandaged up.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And also remember at the beginning of a book to make an incision of their veins and to remove those in the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 On the removal of a vein in front of an incision made for removing the brain
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 In order to remove a vein in front of an incision made for removing the brain, it is necessary first to make the incision for removing the brain; and after that you will be able to apply cold water on the face, and then move up and down (the vein); and afterwards press upon it with your finger, so as to squeeze out the blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 The quality of the removed vein is such that you can narrow them by using your fingers.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 If a man falls down while he is drinking water, until his head appears again.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then you will take the tool that is called an "Fossorium".
Cuius haec est forma.	 The shape of this tool is such that it can be used to remove veins and also draw blood from them.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 With the top part of the "Fossorium" you should press against this vein from above with your finger or with another object, so as to squeeze out blood; and then release it while drawing it in according to the quantity that is necessary for this process.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then you should make a small incision on it, and hold tight until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes when the vein is opened with the "Fossorium" on one side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However it should not be so that you make an incision at the end of a vein as sharp and sudden as when removing others, but rather let it come to an end gradually.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 And you should remove the vein by turning on that side, as its position is next to one of your fingers; and there may be a risk that when it is soft and gentle with the "Fossorium" will break away or fall off.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 On the removal of veins from two lachrymal canals (the tear ducts).
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 In order to remove veins from the two tear ducts of both eyes you need first a small incision on each side at the corner of the eye; and afterwards apply cold water on the eye, and then move up and down with your fingers over it, so as to squeeze out the blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 The quality of these veins is such that you can narrow them by using your fingers.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then you should remove the veins; and with both hands hold tightly over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 "In order for a vein to be cut short and as short as possible without using scissors that are too small or too large, the veins should be cut at an equal length.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 "If a phlebotomist cuts off a vein in half then it will break (in two).
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 "After that you should draw out blood from the patient as much as is necessary.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 "Put a bandage over them and bind them up at night every day.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 "In the case of removing veins from patients who have many veins (like in the hand).
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 "In the case of removing veins from patients who have many veins (like in the hand), this will cause fever and chills, and a burning sensation on the face. This is particularly true when the patient has old scars.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 "The quality of the phlebotomy should be such that it leaves the patient weak in their lower half (like in a leg).
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 "After that you should hold the patient's left hand and take a fine phlebotomist with a long needle; then pierce it at its junction (between the thumb and index finger).
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 "Because one finger does not feel anything there because blood starts to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 "And it is necessary that you hold your hand with a phlebotomist longer and draw out blood from the patient according to your needs.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 "Then bind them up at night every day.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 "The cut will heal quickly or not.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 "In the case of removing veins from guide-patients (like in the foot).
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 "In the case of removing veins from guide-patients (like in the foot), there is a strong desire to constrict them and get rid of leprosy sores on their feet.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 "The quality of the phlebotomy for guide-patients (like in the foot) is such that it leaves them weak on both sides and they will lie flat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 "In the case of removing veins from patients with many veins, you should cut a vein to its maximum length without using scissors that are too small or too large.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 "Then you should extract from blood a certain quantity of heat.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Afterwards do the same with another vein
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 After this, apply a ligature to both veins and tighten them in such a way that the weaker of the two will not be weakened.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And then remove it from its head.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 Then cleanse the wound.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 "The art of bleeding veins by Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 The art of bleeding veins by Albucasis is as follows: when you are about to bleed a vein, and the vein gets into your mouth or nose, do not let it go down your throat; instead, cleanse with a sponge soaked in alcohol, remove any bad ulcers from the gums, and clean wounds on face, arms, and any other part of his body.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 The quality of bleeding veins is that you should let the patient remain in a lying position before doing so; and tie down his head with a cord.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Afterwards remove his lips and look at both veins closely; one of them will be in the right lower lip, and the other in the left side of his neck; their demonstration is through black marks on either side.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 It should be done this way because veins are minute, dark-colored markings can be seen in the surroundings.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Then cut off both of them with one stroke.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 If there is doubt on your part or you do not know which veins are being referred to here, then intend a larger cut and one that shows the veins more clearly.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And do similarly to both veins on the upper lip and customarily with that, and make two cuts from the lower lip as well.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 "The art of bleeding veins under the tongue after cephalic vein.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 The two veins under the tongue are being referred to here; it is important that the art of bleeding the cephalic vein has been done before this one.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 The quality of bleeding them is that the patient should remain in your hands facing you; lift up his tongue from the left side and look at one vein on the right side, then do the same for the other vein; their demonstration is through black marks both sides.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 Phlebitis, therefore both of them keep watch, lest your hand be cut off by phlebotomy
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 They are veins (arteries). It is possible that the flow of blood may be hindered from these veins (arteries).
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 Of three veins in a bundle.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are commonly used to tie up into a bundle for phlebotomy (bloodletting) are found throughout all humans.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 The bloodletting of these veins can be done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Either by piercing with a lancet and applying the cupped hand to the vein or by gently pulling out while using a small knife (or spoon): or by cutting off part of the vein with a phlebotomist's tool.
Et haec est forma eius.	 This is their form for this purpose.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 Thus it was agreed upon as the method of cutting off or severing (removing) a vein.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And from these are large and small veins, depending on the size of the vein(s) and the restriction thereof. The form for using a cupped hand (myrtin) is wide as you can see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 And agreed upon the opening of various types of veins (large ones, filled with blood, prominent ones, large and turgid ones, and those that contain a great deal of turbid blood).
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 The phlebotomist is smaller in size than the veins themselves but more skilled at their operation.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 And agreed upon the bloodletting of the smallest veins that contain clear blood (bright red).
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 The bloodletting of the basilica or veinlet
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 The basilica is one bundle out of three veins used in phlebotomy (bloodletting).
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 The basilica was used to extract blood from the jugular veins underneath and around the neck, following which the chest is drawn out towards it: and the phlebotomist agreed with the phlebomant (bloodletter) that they should tie off this vein so as to close it completely, lest there be a flow of blood through or into it, because beneath it lies an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If the basilica should err (be damaged) and be pierced by a phlebotomist's lancet, it will hit that artery, and there may be an obstruction of blood flow.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 "You must prevent a vein from being cut when another person is performing a phlebotomy on it.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the manifestation of the basilica is not visible, then you must prevent it from being cut when another person performs a phlebotomy on it. You may either move (it) to another or seek another who can perform a phlebotomy on that vein. Or, if someone else's arm has been cut at that location, you should remove his arm and perform the phlebotomy there instead of where he was originally injured.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 That vein is visible and must be treated as stated earlier.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If you are performing a phlebotomy on the same arm, then it is necessary to check for any previous injury and perform the procedure at an appropriate place until you know where that point is.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 After the incision has been made and cauterized with a hot iron, remove the arm afterward to perform the phlebotomy on that same location as we stated earlier.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 Prevent cuts from occurring at or near blood vessels.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 After you've tied off the ligature and cauterized with an iron at that location, then inflation of that artery occurred; therefore remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood rising during a phlebotomy procedure, act like a child and treat it as if there is urine (bleeding), but know that it is from an artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 After that, place your finger above the space for a long time and then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If you see that the blood has been cut off or is about to be cut off and then tie it back up quickly; prevent an injury by preventing sudden movement of the arm, so that there will be no shock from its movement.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And do not let him move around for a long time until he has healed completely.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 If the blood is not cut off and you see it coming to your finger; then strike that artery.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 The opposite arm or hand is brought against him in order to prevent bleeding from occurring.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or accept a tourniquet from the other person and find him; take one dose of medicine and tie it above that cut, with cordage and powder until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 This is a medieval Latin translation of an Arabic medical text written by Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi in the 10th century. The translation reads "When blood is cut off, it's good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 "However if not (i.e., when blood is not cut off), the cautery is performed upon it from its location where the previous bleeding occurred and because of the flow of the blood: and making a cut on the vein to prevent further loss, since the removal of that part might be difficult in multiple dispositions due to the narrow space available, and by ligating the artery with a bandage.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 "Of young veins.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 "The method for young veins is different from the old ones. The former takes blood from the superior part of the head and the inferior part of the body due to their composition being formed by the branches of the basilar artery and cephalic vein.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 "And he cautorized it so that its blood would be taken out under tension since there is a vein underneath of it.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 "Therefore if he added that to the phlebotomy, and a vein was found underneath it, there occurred a fall into unconsciousness due to a sudden pressure change; but its treatment became difficult, and in some cases not successful.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 "As for many veins being present under the skin.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 "However if veins were occulted in some men and are subtle but not visible; then it is necessary that you perform your phlebotomy as follows: first cauterize with the alnasel until the blood stops flowing, and then make a small cut on them applying your bandage forcefully.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 "But if one vein is between two veins, then find its length first.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 "Of the cephalic (neck) vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 The method for young cephalic veins is different from the old ones. They take blood from the head and flow downwards towards the eyes due to their composition being formed by the branch of the basilar artery.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 "And you should perform this one when it is present and ready; so if you're able to cautorize with the phlebotomist of oil (using olive-oil based salve), or with that of myrtle (a different kind of balm).
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 In spite of this, if you wish to touch the veins, you should hold onto his head and gently squeeze until it becomes numb. Then, seek a more favorable location for further treatment; but do not hurt him while he is still moving as that would cause harm.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 In some men, when the veins are not touched by a first blow (i.e., when a vein is not struck or hit), it doesn't hurt them at all; they endure it easily and without any harm.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 Of the usefulness of phlebotomy: Pay attention to its details.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The quality and accidents associated with phlebotomy, which you should consider when correcting it.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 First of all, you should know that phlebotomy is not to be administered unless for the sake of health preservation and treatment; it's also important to avoid any injury from an untimely arrival (i.e., to arrive too early).
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 So that phlebotomy is given through the three veins which are located at the top of the arm: namely, the cephalic vein, the basilic vein, and the brachial vein.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 So that phlebotomy is given at the beginning of fasting (i.e., before meals), or after breakfast and dinner; if it's not done within a short period of time, its effects may cause swelling.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 So that phlebotomy is given on the first or third day after three hours have passed since the previous phlebotomy.
