Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	 And as the length of the fracture increases, then the ligature will decrease in length.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	 If you have everything ready and the ligation is placed as I described it at that time when you will restore the member quickly, then do this: if by chance she escapes from her cold ligature, then release the restraint and let her go until seven days have passed.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	 "In considering a ligature for three days, ensure that it does not cause itching or swelling at the site where it is applied, nor shall it be removed from the body by force, due to the constriction of fluids.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	 Therefore, let this be done as we have said so.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	 "If it is too close to the skin, then do not let anything come from it; for three days at most, unless otherwise specified.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	 "The nurse should lie down on his back and hold his hand above his belly; and place under the support there fill a full sack of equal weight.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	 "And consider at every hour of the night or day that it does not remove or soften the fractured member, nor ease the ligature.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	 "Therefore, do this with your skill.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	 "Place food for the nurse according to our order so that his mouth is first fed and does not start choking; then he must eat as much as possible.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	 "Therefore it is customary for the nurse to bind his hands and feet with ligatures for forty days; then he must be given water so that he may drink, and a bath will be provided for him, and medicated with oils that are suitable.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	 "If a fracture has occurred in the body, bind it tightly; then remove the ligatures and fasten them until fifty days have passed, or two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	 "Of the restoration of the arm's broken bone.
Caput XIII.	 "Chapter 13: Restoration of Fractured Bones.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	 "The arm is composed of two bones called the forefinger and thumb.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	 "One bone of it is small; that one follows the hand.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	 "The other bone is large and is placed below a smaller part from below.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	 "Therefore the larger bone may be broken along with it by the small one, or the small one alone; and sometimes both are broken together.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	 "Therefore, when the larger bone is broken by the smaller one at its top, then the restoration and healing of it are easy.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	 When the lower eyelid is broken, it's a bad injury and healing for it is difficult
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	 When both upper eyelids are broken simultaneously, that causes great damage.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	 If only the upper eyelid is broken, then it should be treated by a physician as soon as possible so that he can apply a patch to cover up the defect and make things equal.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	 If the upper eyelid is very broken (i.e., badly injured), then it should be treated by a physician as soon as possible so that he can apply a stronger patch to cover up the defect.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	 It is necessary for him to have someone else apply a mask over his face during treatment and to stretch it as much as possible above the eyebrows.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	 The hand should be placed on the upper eyelid and all other fingers of both hands except for one that is broken or disabled should point downward to protect his face from injury while he lies flat down.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	 After applying the patch, stretch the arm above him using a bandage if necessary.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	 And another person extends it from the other side in the same way.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	 After applying both patches and stretching them as far as possible, the physician should make things equal to him by reducing the difference between his two eyes according to what he can do.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	 If both upper eyelids are broken simultaneously, then you should reduce each of them separately where they were broken with your strength.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	 If you see a defect separately from it and mark it with ink so that it is not lost to you; then find something above him similar to what we described for the patches on both eyes, and apply it as far as possible over his face according to how much was done in the ones that were applied.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	 If a defect is caused by injury and I have already provided a separate bandage for it separately; then take care of him from that point on.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	 If the bandage on your face turns cold in the beginning of your treatment and you need a warm one; then use a warm, white patch with some oil or rose water mixed into it to keep his eyes moist, but don't let it drip off him as he sits there, until after applying both patches everything is equal. Then remove the warm bandage and apply another fresh one made from flour and egg whites that you can mix together in a similar way for each patch separately.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	 "In place of stars, put another one that is placed above the cut in a manner wider than it and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	 "You know that the number of stars in the arm is six depending on their arrangement; either there should be one fracture in one pair of scissors or two fractures in two pairs of scissors.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	 "And place your own stricter over the fracture of strength more and stronger than it, as well as some amount with a stricter above the fracture or below; either place the stricter milder over his own fracture instead, remembering that this was mentioned at the beginning of the chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	 "And there are those wrapping around a fracture, with loose ones and wet; they should not be hard or sharp.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	 "And it is the thread that is stretched from linen itself, in between subtle and coarse like we mentioned.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	 "And consider the member and ligament after a day.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	 "If you want to apply something whose rectification is necessary, as itching that strikes a member; then there should be such as the member becomes heated with water until the itch stops and the member is not twisted, in order for him to stop, after that stricter.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	 "If the stricter has already been made milder and removed its mouth as well as similar ones; then rectify that thing with your own strength and consider it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	 "If food is prohibited from being given to the member due to excess in stricter, then there should be such that it becomes milder instead and you remove him for a certain number of days until he comes back; after that you should stretch it.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	 "If on the other hand none of those things listed struck you with weakness, then there is no need to do it unless after one day or around them.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	 "Then your hands should be held weakly against his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	 "And the neck of him is equal and he should protect himself with his strength from movements that are agitated.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	 "And make him sleep on top of his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	 "It is known that this fracture will be restored within 30 days or 29 days; and possibly it will take more than one month.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	 It depends on the dispositions of the complexion and virtues.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	 On how to restore a fracture with the hand
Caput XIIII.	 The twelfth book.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	 It is known that the fingers of the hand are rarely injured by a fracture of the thumb.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	 And it did not happen to him unless there was excessive atrophy beforehand.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	 When the plants are fractured due to their own structure, it is necessary that he lie down flat; and his body should be placed symmetrically about him as though lying on his side.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	 Then place one of his hands upon her extended arm.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	 Then he extends the broken bones and arranges them symmetrically; until they are held together by a good jointing.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	 When it is necessary to lay the plaster and bandage on him, unless there has been severe cold injury.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	 Then place a star above according to its quantity; you have now covered it with linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	 If the plants are fractured on all sides except below, then make a ball of linen cloth; and place the weakened one upon it in such a way that he holds onto it with his fractured plant. Then tie him up with long cloth after this manner.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	 And the star should be of lead; so that it is rubbed against his body until he is covered with a plant's skin; and tie her up as necessary.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	 If the plants are fractured on all sides except below, then place a star above; and another one of them from below upon the plant; have his hand open straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	 Then tie it up as before with the hand, so that he extends between the fingers by a cord.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	 If one of his fingers is fractured, then it should be placed as necessary to the side.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	 "After the application of a plant, if you are in love with it, apply to it an appropriate star, and then bind the wound with sinew so that it does not move.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	 "If the fracture is in any other digit except for the middle one, then bind it just as you would with the thumb and forefinger or ear lobe; at that point it will heal well, and if done correctly, all of them are bound together [in a similar manner] and it works better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	 "Or you can apply the star to the top with sinew as I mentioned for the thumb; this will also heal well if done correctly.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	 "And consider the restoration of yours and after its placement be careful with your hands in a gentle manner; hold it tightly when something happens to it from that moment on according to how its story is told.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	 "On the restoration of the fracture of the tibia.
Caput XV.	 "Head XV.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	 "The shin bone is often broken and declared to the interior and exterior parts.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 "And the restoration of it happens like this, where you bind sinew above the fracture and another one below it.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	 "And with his leg stretched out in front of him.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	 "Then he extends all ligaments so that they are equally balanced on the part and this is when there is a fracture in the middle of the bones.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 "If the fracture is close to the shin bone's root, then it will be sinew bound to the chin side so that the extension goes upwards and another one below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	 "And in similar fashion if there is a fracture close to the knee, then it will be sinew bound near the knee so that the extension goes downwards.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	 "Then the physician equalizes both hands with their own sinew and until it is reduced to its proper shape according to the nature of the figure; it is then bound together through a good connection.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	 "Then you must apply plaster and bandage if there was no damage to that member.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	 "If you injured it then remove the plaster and bandage after a few days so that the member is cold; thereafter return to your care.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	 The stricture is such and so
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	 A stricture should be removed by applying pressure to it from both sides until the bone is broken through its thickness. That means binding and stretching simultaneously on one side or two sides alternately while pulling out excess flesh
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	 Afterward, apply pressure to the heel from beneath it until both are released.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	 Insert a long thread between the thigh and calf up to the knee near the bottom, so that both extremities extend from the top of one half of the body parts to the top of another half.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	 Afterward release pressure on the thigh and calf which is excess from beneath it.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	 Afterward place a stick over the thigh where the fracture was made above this, and then apply one stick on top of the heel.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	 After that, attach both thighs with strips to equalize pressure so as not to damage the bone from too much force.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	 Begin by applying pressure with great force at its middle where the fracture is made through three or four solutions.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	 And if you make the strip longer at the place of the fracture so that it becomes smaller and softer and less tough.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	 Afterward, attach both extremities to each other as before between thighs and calf.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	 Finally tie three sticks which are above with one another.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	 Afterward push downward on both extremities to the foot so that you break it free from below.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	 And tie together also the extremities of sticks with one another, in order not to remove the ligament at its place itself.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	 Afterward release pressure on this so that there is no damage to the member or limb from below, nor breakage of the nail, nor swelling, and similar things.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	 If you do not succeed in removing it without harm
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	 And repeat the solution to that place until it is corrected as described many times before.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	 If you are unable to remove by bone what bites the bone then you must apply pressure from above until that is equal if it is possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	 If not found, remove it and cure what precedes it until it is healed
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	 And when the heel fracture occurs without adding stars to it, just as we said in support and arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	 However, in restoring such a fracture, there is no risk of paralysis or weakness.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	 If it is restored only, without applying another heel to it, then he must walk with the one that belongs to him always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	 And you know that the heel is stretched for 50 days or added and reduced according to its different kinds of complexion and disposition.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	 Of the restoration of the bone fracture in the knee.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter Sixteen
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	 You know that bone fractures are rare in the leg but often occur due to wear and tear.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	 If it occurs only to him as a fracture, then either an opening or a hole should be made on its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	 This is with the aid of a tool and without one.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	 And it is raised entirely with the help of understanding.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	 The restoration of that is thus done so that the restored thing matches what was torn from its parts with your hands until it is complete and then connected according to what can be derived by calculation and ease, and making.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	 Then place a plaster of flour and egg white or milk on it; and put over that round stars if they are ready; and stretch it with strength above as much as to it.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	 Then consider all the dispositions that we mentioned in other fractures; such as cold irons and similar things; so that you should act with everything that can happen to him until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	 Of the restoration of the bone fracture in the knee joint.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter Seventeen
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	 You know that the knee has two bones; one is large and named after it, and the other is fine and called phalanges.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	 "A bone was broken in two places and as a result of this injury the arm had to be restored; thus restoring an equal limb to its original state.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	 "If two bones are simultaneously broken, it becomes an emergency situation where all parts become converted (reassembled).
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	 "If a bone is fractured slightly, only the anterior portion is restored.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	 "If a larger bone is broken, it will be inferior to that which was not hidden from you; and this operation must not obscure what is not hidden from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	 "Then administer the correct stretching, straightening, and stitching as needed according to it in equal measure.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	 "However, if the arm is broken and there are many injuries present (as in a battle), let extension be shorter than normal and healing take longer.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	 "And in the arm there is an operation performed on top of the arm; and it will be as if you have equally stretched the elbows, and completely perform all your operations. Take two cords from the pinewood which is put down under tables: and they are to become like the palm branches: and choose those with a larger size, not from small ones: and its length should be according to the length of the arm from the elbow downwards.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	 "Then bind the skin with two stitches on both sides according to the length of it.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	 "Put one part of the arm onto another and alternate them from elbow to heel.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	 "Then tie two cords with three stitches, at each end, equally spaced.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	 "As long as the arm is in its correct position and you continue to administer correctly, it will recover.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	 "Then administer the bandage from the wood according to the length of the arm and put it on the arm so that it supports him with movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	 "Moreover, if there is a fracture when it has not been caused by an external injury, you should do more of these operations as needed.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	 On the final day of each week and during every study session with him until he is exhausted from fasting or other external causes
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	 If something happens to him during that period of time (that he is studying with Albucasis), then let the following be done by his side: whatever needs doing until such a point as God wills it should be done.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	 Regarding the bones and joints of the foot and hand.
Caput XVIII.	 The eighteenth book
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	 Only once during that period did he suffer a break in his ankle.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	 Regarding the bones of the foot and hand sometimes fractures occur and so do fractures of the fingers; but not all at once unless there is a fall in several positions.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	 If the foot's bone is broken then he lifts his leg to rest on the ground as an invalid does when he falls.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	 Then you lie down and place your foot on what has been made by the broken bones; later praise it, or call out for help; but until then keep still and be quiet where you are.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	 Then he lays his mat beneath him and places a thin plank beneath each foot having two flat surfaces.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	 Then tie it down with the other end after you have used it as a pillow and the others to whom it is appropriate.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	 After three days or four, then let the rope go loose.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	 You make sure both the bones and joints are either broken, fractured, or dislocated when you put on your shoes and boots.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	 The operation is done there as such.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	 If any of your fingers break then you restore them and do the same for each finger that I showed you how to repair hands.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	 Then you place your finger's astillam according to the length of each finger and make it wider than that; then you put under the foot this plank as I showed you how to do and tie it down with the rope securely.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	 If the bone is broken into two or three pieces, then hold onto all of them with a single finger and use that to draw out the string on the palm: And when you have drawn it down through the heel of one foot, let its tail hang outside as you keep tension by holding both ends.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	 And when you have done this, do not neglect the things I told you about other broken bones and all that pertains to accidents we mentioned; for oppose every accident with what is necessary.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	 About the fracture of a woman's ulna bone, in her arm and man's arm.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter Nineteen
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	 When a woman's ulna breaks, hold it with a square grip.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	 Then tilt her towards the side of her back further and hold onto the rear end.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	 The midwife will then apply a dressing to it until she has applied it evenly; and make the ulna into a sphere as smooth as if made of wax.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	 Then the woman lies down and stretches out her arm gently.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	 And this will be done until it has become level in front of the ulna like a sphere; and its mouth is broken open.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	 Then place a small sponge over her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	 When he is done kneading gently and has moved it onto her back, then knead lightly; reduce by the same amount you reduced it by initially; and then move it towards its first sponge again.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	 It will be done in seven days or as near to that time; for indeed he will restore the mouth of it back whole.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	 And if there is an obstruction, take the hollow sheath of the bone; and tighten it onto its canal with the help of the tendons; insert the whole sheath into the ulna of her.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	 Then blow gently through it until the sheath is inflated inside the ulna; for indeed its mouth will be broken.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	 Then apply a dressing to it and hold off some days until we have spoken as to when it should be done; for indeed it will heal.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	 When the windpipe is broken either by man or woman then administer to restoration of it, and its balance will be found as we have described it in the bone of Anchae
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	 Nor should a man's or woman's rectum be hidden when it is broken, which rarely happens and especially to those who have much study or use
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	 And read my book thoroughly, for the fracture itself means to you that the right of restoration and the restraint on it are many. Therefore understand
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	 When a man's windpipe is broken, take the bird feathers; insert them into him.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	 Then place over it a solution from the cloth and it is done (i.e., insert into him), or otherwise as many days as there are until he becomes better if God willed it
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	 For the restoration of bones when there's a fracture with a bone.
Caput XX.	 Head XX
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	 He who has a bone fracture with a blow to the head is especially treated as if it were the pelvis or assistant's hand, in order that he may be quickly relieved by phlebotomy; should you find conditions for phlebotomy (i.e., symptoms) according to our description.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	 If the blow caused blood to flow, then immediately apply phlebotomy so that the ulcers are removed; if not present at your hand, you must apply immediately as described.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	 Then begin to restore the fracture on that day itself and do not delay it, if no other has been hit by an arrow.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	 If a hot arrow has struck him then postpone the restoration of his fracture until after one day; until he no longer feels pain from the arrow.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	 Do not approach to him on the third and fourth days, nor thereafter if you were to bring upon him bad accidents.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	 If the windpipe is broken high above the throat then it must be reduced to its place with you, and made equal with your hands in ease and extent.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	 If the extension is not prepared for him and his balance cannot be restored by your hands, then reduce it to this instrument
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 It is an instrument made of iron, the length of which is equal to seven or eight digits; and its breadth is proportional to the amount of your nails
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	 For that reason it is necessary for a doctor to take three or four of them according to the amount he needs from this instrument after being broken in all respects
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	 It is round; and its size is equal to that of a pear so as not to be doubled up when compressed during the time of an operation; but it has sharp edges such that there is room for the fingers on both sides of itself.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	 It sits above with respect to its size, from just below it up to the bottom.
Et haec est forma eius.	 This is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	 It is suitable for this operation so that its sharp edge can be placed on the protruding finger or thumb; and with it alone pull back when he has emptied his mouth and reaches an equilibrium through some balance.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	 Therefore, align both fractured limbs in one direction.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	 If the limbs of his are broken and he cannot grasp it with a good grip because of that, then let him try to strike one of its extremities onto another extremity of his own, until the instrument has power over him.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	 If you cannot reduce them with him as we have described, then strike him with an instrument in any way that is possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	 After striking it to the bone from its sharpness and fine texture, release your own weapon.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	 Therefore, when you have reduced the mouth and he is relieved from severe pain, then know that his mouth cannot return to its original position.
Fac ergo illud.	 Do this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	 Thus the restoration of your strength is completed as you have done with your hands.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	 "The finger must be washed with vinegar.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	 And it is proper that there should be water used for washing.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	 Nor apply any oil above the nail, lest it cause infection and decay of the flesh near it.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	 Then administer the pills to you at your hour for restoration of bones.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 Then wash off the finger nails so that you strike with a hammer through the holes into the proper position according to quantity of bones.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	 Be careful not to pull the nail apart when it breaks.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	 Many surgeons of old did practice this method on the sick or dying, causing death by cutting through bones and flesh, eating away at the bone itself, i.e., the bone was eaten up.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	 Your grip should be soft, flexible, different from those of broken bones' remnants.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	 If the nail is bad or large, and some very bad accidents happen on top of it, causing great pain near the spot; then you should not apply anything above that at all.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	 Then provide solutions from hard nails in place so they can be struck with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	 When the day has passed one or two days and you see the nail starting to grow, then wash it off with vinegar above where you placed it on top of itself using vinegar.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	 Then administer the medicines and ointments as we have always done for our wounds; such as the ointment Tetrapharmacion, and similar ones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	 And it is fitting to you so that there are only bonds left.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	 Consider the nail every day morning and evening until it settles down and heals.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	 It is fitting that you will prepare the body in this manner so that the discharge from above may go down to below with ease.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	 If many days pass and it does not heal or consolidate, then you know that the bones near there are already broken off.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	 Certainly! The Latin phrase translated directly from medieval Arabic is "When you seek (for something), grasp it with your hands.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	 Indeed, when removed are the attachments that bind them apart, remove her and then take her herself.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	 And when those that are not detached remain attached to it and cause it pain by grasping the part of it, strike her with a blow so as to release her from all manner of binding constraints and obtain her in any way possible for you that thing.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	 When you strike the bound one with a blow or tear him apart, that is to say, either remove his head from among those who have been mentioned earlier and those who have been corrupted by putrefaction, or take some other way of escape; then it is necessary for you, having come to grips with each one as he has provided in his chapter on this matter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	 And from that in which it is necessary for me to remain silent when the mouth breaks and blood flows forth from between the teeth like those of a horse or dog, and those who provide support, and similar large ones among them; so as not to give him excessive attraction, since often death comes by this way too. So I let go of him until he has putrefied.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	 Indeed, if you stay alive for more than 21 days or 30.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	 Then give him a cure when it seems to you, and otherwise release him.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	 About the care of fractures that occur through the use of ropes or cords.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter 21
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	 Often death comes by this kind of treatment for fractures that occur through the use of ropes or cords.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	 Especially when it is about stitches; and it becomes detached from that figure on a member.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	 And sometimes it prevents the member's natural use of his own body.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	 Therefore consider at that point if the treatment is with a rope; administer medicines containing astringency like aloe and myrrh, and others, and bitter substances such as acacia.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	 In that case, either grasp some of those with a rope or all at once; and bind them with wine or vinegar or acid (wine acidity); then place them on the knotting above it, and tie them tight to the same good suture.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	 "Remove the stricture but not its cause from many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	 "Then remove that thing and try another one until the blockage is removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	 "Cut through the same membrane from both ends with a sharp knife.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	 "The membrane is the property that needs to be removed, which cannot be done without cutting into it from both sides.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 "If the blockage is in a stone and tight and pressing urgently for removal, then find it from above his part, and cut off excess material to one side with some forceps until it can be removed; then treat that which was found, so that it may heal.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	 "After the membrane is restored and remains after this subtle, not according to its nature.
Caput XXII.	 "Chapter 22.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	 "When the fracture of the bones is restored and the membrane after it remains subtle and weak, then that thing cannot be done except for many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	 "Of one there is a solution and ligature of his; not according to what should be done but for many reasons: either the ligament's stricture or the excessive embrocation, until the nutrition run to it may be prohibited: or for too much abundance in non-his hour: or for lack of blood in the weak body, and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	 "The care of it is to feed a sick one, to make his body strong until he may multiply blood within him.
Et administra balneum.	 "And administer the medicine.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	 "And insert joy and gladness upon it [the sick person].
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	 "Then place a needle over the membrane so that many a picture can be drawn into him with much nourishment.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	 "And diligently administer to him with hot water so that the nourishment may run through it and return to its own nature.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	 "About the care of fractured bones when they are restored in a tortuous manner.
Caput XXIII.	 "Chapter 23.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	 "When the member already restored after healing of it tortuousness has come upon him or a blockage and its form becomes a member, yet the membrane cannot be prohibited from its operation naturally; therefore one does not need to give a sermon to him who exists so that he may break it with force.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	 "Many surgeons and restorers have come from foreign lands.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	 This operation is extremely difficult to perform, either causing death or great fear, so that it may be called fatal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	 The recent collapse and paralysis require a treatment with hot water; boiled herbs should be used that are soothing, such as those of the elder tree, its root, mallow, and others like them.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	 A plaster made with softened linen should also be applied; it is effective for relaxing muscles.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	 Or mallow roots can be used, or the lard of geese could also work; or you might use olive oil as well and apply them both.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	 Or fig leaves can be used too; or you might use pine resin mixed with columbine and other such things that help reduce swelling.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	 And sometimes paralysis can be treated by a combination of persistent friction, ancient, and gentle, which is like the treatment using human hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	 The limbs should be gently moved to all parts of the body in every direction possible.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	 If the body is already rigid and has been overcome with strong measures, then a firm grip of stone should be obtained to remove him from there; continue the treatment with the use of hands and incisions must also be made for those that are left behind due to the removal of swelling or bones with sharp instruments. And it should be applied with ease in this way using eagerness and persistence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	 Of the dislocation of the tongue.
Caput XXIIII.	 The 24th head
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	 Dislocation is the exit from the joint, where it was.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	 Because of this, motion should be avoided and the member's appearance restored.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	 It causes injuries to the sick and those who are already injured.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	 Therefore, when a dislocation occurs, it is necessary then to take immediate action for its restoration; there should be no delay whatsoever.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	 "When time is delayed, separation occurs at that place, and sometimes with it reduction of dislocations.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	 Therefore, it should not be done to prevent delay so that extension does not occur during the time of his separation.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	 Because many things cause spasms and pain accompanying them
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	 Indeed when that happens, then it is necessary to order an intravenous infusion of fluids.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	 Afterwards, until he has stopped moving away from the time of separation.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	 Afterwards it is moistened with a warm bath and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	 Afterwards, it can be reduced easily.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And everything else is cured along with that memory that has forgotten its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	 I have already ordered the bones of the dislocated, and also according to what preceded it in fracture, going from the upper part of his body all the way down to its lower part.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	 Treatment for the lower jaw bone dislocation.
Caput XXV.	 The 25th chapter
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	 The two jaws are rarely dislocated.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	 And the dislocation of both is done in a manner similar to one of them.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	 Or they may be separated by movement from their places and softened slightly.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	 Or they may be separated by a complete dislocation until they are softened to the point of the chest and saliva is released as well as she can no longer hold her mouth shut and her tongue slips out with words.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	 When their dislocation occurs suddenly they return to many positions by themselves with a few, but when it is complete then they are returned to the normal position on their own.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	 If the dislocation is complete and integral then it needs to be treated immediately either with immediate reduction or otherwise; and it is important that he holds on tight by having the head held by someone else so as not to miss out on any pain, whether it was due to one part or another of his jaw.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	 Or if both jaws are dislocated then he holds onto two fingers each at once.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	 The fingers are removed from his hand
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	 And he will perform the surgery with great care and precision; freeing them to move the hands up and down at all times.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 The surgeon adjusts the amputated limbs and propels them until they reach their proper place (wherever that may be).
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	 If the surgery is difficult for him, especially if both hands are affected simultaneously; in that case he administers a mixture of warm water and oil to facilitate the process, until they become easier to separate (from each other).
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	 When they become equal and relaxed, and the arms weaken but do not soften (i.e., don't lose their firmness), then he places them over some kind of padding or cushion with a layer of wax on top; and oil is used for lubrication.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	 After that, they are tightened up again using soft bandages to regain some of the strength which had been lost.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	 He then sleeps on his back with a pillow between his head and two arms to prevent him from rolling over; not to chew or swallow anything (i.e., nothing goes down the throat). His mouth is bound gently in order that he may take only small sips of something, until the pain decreases and his limb is loosened up enough for the doctor to administer it with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	 He does not eat anything by mouth during or after surgery and avoids breathing in any air; he is given something to take orally until his arm is loosened up enough for him to swallow normally (i.e., he's given food).
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	 If the surgery is difficult for both arms at once and they become dislocated, then it may be necessary to apply heat frequently (in addition to oil) until they return to their proper place; there are also instances of severe fevers and heavy sweating that require additional measures or a change in diet towards purgatives.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	 When you know this has occurred, remember that it is a serious loss and many people who have suffered from such a thing may die within 10 days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	 The reduction of dislocations in the elbow (forearm) or any part of the arm
Caput XXVI.	 Twenty-sixth head
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	 The furcula cannot be dislocated from its own place because of its connection to the chest wall.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	 However, it may sometimes be dislocated externally; and this is felt by the sense.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	 The restoration of its connection to the chest wall allows for relief on the back and extending of the arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	 Therefore, when you join your palm with the right hand's strong grasp, she will be restored.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	 Then place it on her own clasp, and pull gently and firmly, until she is recovered.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	 Those that follow the elbow joint remain in their place, continuing with them without dislocation, unless rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	 Whenever it is dislocated on one day; then you must reduce and equalize it according to what we have said, and prepare yourself for it.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	 Then place her back into her own clasp, and pull gently but firmly until she is restored.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	 And you must gently hold the injured one, with ease and tranquility, until he recovers his strength.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	 And with this same care, the extremity of the arm is reduced when it is separated even from its own place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	 Of the reduction of dislocated arms.
Caput XXVII.	 Twenty-seventh head.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	 It is known that the arm cannot be dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	 The first way is to dislocate it so that its lower end is pulled upwards towards the tip of a finger.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	 The second way is to dislocate it from near the chest wall.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	 And perhaps it may be dislocated externally towards the top of the arm; but this is rare.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	 It cannot be dislocated backwards for fear of hitting the shoulder blade.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	 And it cannot be dislocated forwards, due to the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	 It is most likely to dislocate and reduce downwards towards the tip of a finger; especially on those whose flesh is thin.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	 For when you pull it back in quickly, and release it quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	 In those whose flesh is abundant are they opposite one another; for their appetite grows with difficulty and their digestion with difficulty
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	 And some men have died from blows or illness and the arm is torn off by its fellow in a heated state; so that it is dislocated because of this occurrence
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	 Therefore you should seek out what happened to him until he has proven his story and then proceed with the treatment of that part of the body.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	 The dislocation is known when it is below and opposite to the wrist; distinguish between the dislocated arm and the healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	 You will find a difference between the two and distinguish the one at the top of the arm from the other; and you should grasp it under the chin as if it were your own hand so that you cannot weaken its grip on your shoulder but cannot move it with all your movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	 Similarly if the dislocation is above or to the side; then you should find a visible touch and it cannot be hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	 And this kind of dislocation reduces easily when there are no longer any restrictions on his movement or he is young.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	 The reduction of that part will be so you can let your hand go to the top.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	 Then put your fingers under it and gently pull with strength towards the top; you will release the grip while extending to its own place and then let go of the hand.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	 And afterwards he puts her back down below and straight away releases or moves her quickly
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	 If he does not release as we have described and there are many days from the beginning when dislocation occurs; then it is necessary that a cold bath be given to him, so that he may recover through the use of embrocation which soothes and cools just as if the roots were cut off by frost or the leaves of the apple tree wither in water and so on.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	 Then he is placed back down onto his back; and put under it the sphere of wool that lies between restraint and freedom.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	 Then lay the surgeon upon his heel and lift up his head with a stroke of skill, then stretch out his arm to bring it down gently
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	 And another assistant should hold onto the surgeon's head so that it does not move downwards; he himself will soon be lifted up again.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	 And if you wish to bring his body down this way; he will be lifted up by an assistant on the opposite side so that it lies flat and its arm is brought downwards under control of the assistant, then lifted upwards towards himself from there until the limb is held suspended in the air
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	 And another assistant should hold onto the surgeon's hand so that it moves downward; he will be brought up again by an assistant on the opposite side.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	 If the limb is weak and should not move; then it's necessary to hold onto him something else so that he can be lifted up again; as for the dislocation, this will happen quickly.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	 And can also be brought down by another method; as when a long stick with a round head is used so that it may rest on the ground like the hand of death which should not be heavy nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	 Then lay him under after he is laid on a long stick; and then the limb will remain in place according to the length of the stick.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 Then his hand is stretched out to its opposite side and the body from the other side with strength; as for the joining together it will be in place with a firm connection.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	 And if the reduction of his body is difficult through all that we have described; then use this care; and it will be as when you take a stick whose length is equal to the sum of two arms, its width is equal to four fingers, its thickness is equal to the sum of two fingers, its head rounded so that he may be lowered into the depths with control in this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	 Then wrap a soft stick around his round head to prevent him from falling off.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	 Then lay him under the control of an assistant so that his hand may be stretched out or be held by a stick above it all the way down to its opposite side; and bind the stick above the other arm and the end of the hand with binding materials.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	 In order that the arm be placed on the steps and extended downwards towards the lower part of it so that the hand is moved to its lowest extent while leaving the other body suspended in support
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	 The stroke should immediately follow.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	 When the entrance is thus completed according to whatever manner possible, it must be done that one places an equal quantity of wool balls beneath [the patient's] ear.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	 After the above, apply a pre-prepared plaster from flour mixed with water and egg white on all of his body as was done previously.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	 After all of that, tie the plaster bandage tightly and it should be able to hold up well. The arm will then be extended upwards towards its body as was previously mentioned and is left immobilized for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	 It must also be done that the limb of the sick person be placed so as to be in a comfortable position for its recovery since it is one of the means towards his health improvement.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	 After seven days or five, when he's placed on a stretcher and moved to somewhere suitable.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	 If it then becomes firm but does not loosen up, at that time the sick person is cured.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	 If the stroke occurs due to excessive moisture that has happened [to him] or because of another reason, it must be done so that a cautery is administered with three holes as was mentioned before in the chapter on cautery.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	 If everything is done as mentioned above and the bandage loosens after seven days without being tightened up again, it must be cut off and thrown away because it cannot stay fixed to him and he will not be able to raise himself up with his arms stretched out or loosened up either: then you know that the hand injuries are made.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	 Or if a dislocation occurs on the breastbone or nipple, or towards the back, it can be done with the use of force and stretching with the hands until it is no longer there after which the remaining bandage must still be applied so that he may heal.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	 If the wound is treated after a certain period of time has passed and there is swelling and slowness in motion due to it, then that member becomes weak from lack of blood flow many times over, until finally the pain subsides and returns to its original nature
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	 Of dislocations involving the Cubitus.
Caput XXVIII.	 Head 28th.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	 If the cubitus joint is dislocated with difficulty and also returns to its original position with difficulty as well; it itself may dislocate from all parts especially towards the anterior or posterior regions.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	 The dislocation of that joint is not hidden from you because it lies beneath the hand and under touch; according to whatever position it may be dislocated in.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	 When you connect a dislocated Cubitus with a healthy one, that is clearly visible to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	 The joint becomes swollen and cannot simultaneously use the arm; it can only move while separate from it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 It is necessary that you should make haste to restore the joint immediately before any cold comes upon it.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	 If a cold attacks that member, then the reduction of its dislocation becomes difficult; perhaps it will not recover at all, especially if it is towards the posterior region.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	 The dislocation itself has many forms and its pain increases; sometimes they even fall with death accompanying them.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 The restoration of that joint when it can be reduced is as follows: the hand is extended with two hands; the arm is fully expanded and the hands of a physician are above and below the joint, while itself it presses down on the dislocation by using both its hand or the palm's root until it returns to its place.
