Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	 Alternatively the dislocation can be towards the anterior; then it returns in this way to double up its hand with its own hand until it strikes against the dislocated Cubitus's root.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	 If the dislocation cannot be reduced then administer an intensive and strong stretch; it is as follows that two ministers expand the arm while holding onto it from both sides so that it may not be moved away by stretching.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	 After having been moved away from its original position above one's hand due to a broken strap on the forearm or wrist being stretched too far
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	 And when the surgeon joins up with oil on his own hand after having cleaned it himself with lubrication, making use of those that are applied to facilitate the joining process
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	 The joining motion is completed by a strong force.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	 After the reduction of it (the strap) is necessary to put it on top of its own wrapping, which provides support and allows for proper movement; then stretch and tighten with a bow tie in order to achieve the desired tightness.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	 And the arm is lowered from the shoulder to the elbow after having been reduced by a certain amount of time.
Deinde soluatur.	 The motion is completed.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	 If the joining operation becomes solid at its own place, then remove it (the strap) immediately afterwards and dispose of it.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 If you find that the joining is not done properly, then try again with another wrapping and remove (the strap) after a certain amount of time has passed, until tightening occurs.
Deinde solue ipsam.	 The motion is completed.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	 If the joining process causes the strap to be injured after reduction, then make adjustments according to motion; that is, administer wet dressing in bathing water and apply rubbing and compressing techniques until the wound is closed or if it is put over the joining point (the strap), as long as a small piece of flesh remains.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	 And tie up again with another strap after day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	 And remove it afterwards from that place in a bath
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	 After cleaning up, apply rubbing and tightening techniques to the joining operation.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	 Repeat this process with another strap after each one, until it is done properly.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	 If there's a knot above the joining point (the strap), wet it with butter, apply heat and tighten on top of that.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	 Do this repeatedly until it is done properly.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	 The flesh is removed and returned to its own place
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	 Of cuts
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter 29
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	 The hand is cut through multiple times, meaning the incision made between the arm and hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	 Reduction of this injury is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	 After cutting off all fingers
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	 However it is necessary that the wound should be bandaged before it has been dislocated and afterwards, to prevent a cold or hot object from coming into contact with the injury at the time when the dislocation occurs.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	 The reduction of the dislocation is to place a soft bandage over the hand and extend it across so as to support the arm; and then put on the doctor's palm that incision which was made, so that he may move it gently downwards until it becomes detached.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	 However it is necessary to consider if the palm has already retracted towards the other hand; in that case the arm supports its back over the bandage at extension and reduction, so that the hand may be placed on top of the incision with its inside part against the bandage, meaning that only the inner part of the hand should be put on it.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	 If so he does quickly well; and if not, then tie her with a bandage and let him go loose, that is do nothing further.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	 If it does not tolerate the reduction of its dislocation after a day has passed away, then the incision remains as per the tortuousity of its own; and nothing else is harmful except for what softens the hand, nor can anything be tied on; you see that the nails have been broken off or torn.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	 It should not happen by chance but should be bandaged gently for its benefit.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	 And perhaps nothing else may occur.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	 As it does not do with the hand of Almahassem then put a bandage over him so that we might bind or tie it in place.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	 After five days, it is bandaged and then taken off; after that it is soaked in a solution, then wrapped again and used for surgery
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	 If the movement of his hand is restrained and held in that way for some time, it will become soft; he then gently washes it with warm water, rubs it vigorously a few times to soften it, until it becomes soft
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	 Of the treatment for dislocated fingers
Caput XXX.	 Head of John Doe.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	 When the fingers are dislocated in such a way that they touch all parts of the body or rest on the palm of the hand, or between them and you want to release it: first extend your finger(s), then press down on their dislocation with both hands until it is released.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	 After that, support the head of the finger and suspend it towards where it was dislocated, then let it rest for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	 After that, hold him tightly while straightening his fingers, until they are equal to their former state on the day after.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	 When you have finished with him for the night, bind his hand according to its own way of binding and do not relax him during that day; then exercise him with movement, but bind him at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 Do this on several days until it is bandaged.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	 And similarly do with him if the fingers are dislocated between them; bind him to his own way of binding and perform your first surgery on him until he is healed.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	 Do this when they are dislocated in any other part as well.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	 Of the treatment for dislocated shoulders.
Caput XXXI.	 Head of John Doe.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	 If the shoulders are dislocated or completely torn apart by falling forward with both arms at once; do not try to treat it as there is no cure and death comes quickly from weakness.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	 Its sign is that the release of its strength without resistance cannot be held by it; and certain members of his body may lose parts or become weakened in this way from him as well
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	 "Many things are moved when many things move away from each other towards four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	 And if something is moved to the rear part [of the body], it is called gibbositas
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	 Therefore its cure must be sought out if you remember that gibbositas happened to the youth; then there is no care for it, nor any healing from all diseases.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	 But if this happened through case or impact, the ancients said many modes of treatment in a long and difficult speech.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	 Which one did not return with great success.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	 I myself already mentioned that from it to the one whose fault was partly mine and who was nearby my intent: with my exposition which I showed him, and I formed his tool in a different way from how they presented this thing to me
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	 Therefore, that which was moved away from the preceding part of [the body] is not a result of its own nature nor healing by it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	 Similarly, if this happens towards two sides as well.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	 And it is not cured from them except that which happened in the back part as I mentioned; and there was one to extend [the body] upwards towards its own face over a level platform nearly up against the wall: and to expand under him moist bandage so he may not be harmed by his chest.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	 Afterwards, a fixed straight piece of wood is put into the ground at its lower end on the earth; another one around the head and another one around the feet near to the other side [of the foot]; he holds it tight so that it may not be loose in the hole.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	 And the second holds the second piece.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	 Afterwards lift up the head of him with his hands loose but holding it tight; and extend its end to bind that piece at his head firmly and bind him on that part [of the body].
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	 Afterwards tie another piece over his ankles; above his knees too; above his thighs as well; and at his calves [of the legs].
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	 "And remove all ligaments and tie them on another bone which is below his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	 "Then he extended all the ministers to the bone of the ligaments and did not remove two bones from their places where they were fixed; however, these are not set firmly as we said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	 "And the doctor put his hands on the spine with strength until he was exhausted; or placed it on a table.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	 "Then he fixed his feet on top of the table until he was exhausted.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	 "If not by this treatment, then take a tablet whose length is about three times his arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	 "And so put the place where we said it should go near to being weakened and insert the extreme of the tablet into him.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	 "Then he placed a middle tablet on the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	 "And the doctor placed his feet near to another extreme.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	 "Then he tightened well and until it was bent by the spine, and until it was exhausted at its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	 "Afterwards if you are able to operate using a turn-around and what he had used with your hand; it is that way the figure stands on the ground at his head near to two bones of the feet whose length is one arm, and at his feet near to two bones from the feet whose length is also one arm.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	 "The length that is between all the bones of one hand; and it has been done everywhere a hole through which the arrow runs; and every bone will be firmly set down on the ground much.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	 "And an oblong bone is inserted; it was a hole through which he pulled the ligament from two bones of two rods.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	 "And at his extreme there is a hole through which the bone will be fixed whose length is between his hand and what was pulled; and similarly with two other rods.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	 "Then you tighten the ligaments that were torn from his chest using a turn-around which is below his head; and the ligaments that were torn from his limbs with another turn-around which is below his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	 The thumb is held by every surgeon who performs the operation on his hand with a bandage soaked in medicine until the wound has healed completely.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	 This is the form of a tourniquet which follows this pattern.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	 After applying the plaster bandage soaked in excitant oil to the wound and it has been applied evenly, then it is time to apply the tourniquet.
Deinde stuppam.	 The tourniquet must be tightened.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	 After the plaster bandage has been placed and stretched over a surface of three fingers' width or around them, it is necessary to tighten the tourniquet.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	 The length of it should be such that its thickness does not exceed the space between the fingers and is even on the healthy side of the thumb.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	 It must then be tightened with a bandage which we have mentioned before, until complete healing occurs.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	 And it is fed with a subtle nourishment until it heals completely.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	 If anything of importance has happened at the place where healing is occurring and it does not heal completely in its final stages: then it is necessary to administer the medicines that alleviate pain until the bandage has been used for a long time, as mentioned before.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	 And now the bandage soaked in excitant oil must be applied there again.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	 If anything of importance happens at the place where the thumb is being removed and it comes out with a dislocation, then there must be an application of that which has already emerged to restore its function.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	 This is because if he were given this medicine it could potentially cause his death instead of healing him as intended.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	 Of the dislocation of Ancha
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter 32
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	 It is known that the injury to Ancha and the elbow joint did not happen unless it was a dislocation only; neither of them happened as if caused by something else in the other joints' remote places or with violence.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	 The injury to Ancha is done according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 This means that the dislocation of Ancha can happen towards both the front and back of her body.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 The most of it is dislocated towards the internal parts; very little moves towards the front side, and even less towards the rear side.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	 The care of dislocation is towards the internal parts; because when you join a sick limb with a healthy one, it takes longer and there is more upward movement than in the healthy part, but he cannot make both legs stand upright at once on an uneven ground: and there is a track following behind that has been heated up to be able to remove the head from its place.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	 The sign of his dislocation towards the external parts is: it was an injury contrary to these accidents.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	 The sign of his dislocation towards the front side is: it spreads out the healthy limb according to its complement; however, he cannot extend himself without pain in the knee and when walking forward cannot reach the front as well as before, the urine will be retained and the foot behind him will move upwards on the heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	 The sign of his dislocation towards the rear side is: he cannot extend himself and cannot reach forward before extending both legs; there is a shorter leg and the foot behind him will be more bent upwards, and the head behind will remain in its place.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	 The reduction of this dislocation is that you should consider that if it is a false dislocation which has already become old and has been accompanied by the same person in the past.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	 Then if you administer its reduction, it remains according to her own disposition; at that time there is no care for all of them.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	 Therefore, it must not be that he suffers a penalty.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	 In the person whose dislocation is being discussed now and there are four signs of dislocation in him at that time it should be followed as follows to join them together and extend her towards both the internal parts and external parts, and move her with your right and left; for perhaps she will rise up again.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	 If not in this way, then you should prepare a strong remedy and extend her the foot from its lower part; or with your hands, or with a bandage that is tied over her foot above the knee; another one extends his hand on top of it so that he can put his hands underneath hers.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	 "With a ligature tightened above the hip joint and holding with the other ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	 "This is to stretch either towards the anterior aspect of the thigh or to the posterior aspect of the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	 "Or it may be stretched uniformly in all directions until he falls with his body to the ground and remains hanging there.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	 "The nature of this stretch is that of a common stretching for four limbs.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	 "If the dislocation occurs as described, it is good; but if not, then it is necessary to do everything that I have said about self-curating.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 "If the dislocation occurs towards the interior of him when he is in reduction, it should be as if the patient lies on his healthy back.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	 "Thereupon ligatures are placed over the hip joint, in the place between the head of the thigh and the knee.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	 "Then stretches it to the upper aspect of the leg towards the higher part of his body, then to the posterior aspect of the back.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	 "Thereupon takes hold of his stronger arms and makes a large stretch over the injured hip joint, then extends it to the external direction.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	 "I remain in my place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	 "The nature of this stretch is easier than the others that I have described when we are curing a member.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	 "If you fail or can not go on with this stretch when I am curing, then it is necessary to do as follows. Ligate the two lower limbs with one strong ligature and another tight with a ligament over both calves, over both knees, over both thighs: And let each of them be stretched towards his opposite leg four times.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	 "Thereupon the patient is suspended over a beam that lies within our home, and it remains stretched towards each of them as much as two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 "Afterwards command the strong man to support his head and to suspend him with a second ligature; then pull towards each of them and help together by force, for the ligament was attached to its place when it is held by you.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	 In its own version when dislocation occurs to external, it should be necessary that the patient lies on a platform as we illustrated in having a hump or protuberance.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	 And tighten ligaments over his thighs and over his breastbone
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	 Then they are placed two wooden planks, one under the legs of him, and another under the top of his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	 Then the additional wooden plank is placed at the middle of his legs and firmly fixed so that it doesn't allow him to slip away when wet clothes are put over; also a wooden plank should be placed between his thighs to prevent his legs from being pulled downwards by extending movement.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	 Then the assistant moves all the way down to the patient's side and the physician holds back the reduction with their hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	 If so, it is a good thing.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	 And if not, put the same board over his chest and below as we illustrated for the hump or protuberance equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 However, it is necessary that the patient lies on a healthy thigh length wise.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	 When the dislocation is to anterior, then it should be necessary that the patient's leg is extended by his own effort or else he will assist with his right hand and place a palm on the knee of him.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	 Then support him with one other hand while with another he should extend his leg to the lower part of his knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	 If the dislocation is to posterior, then it should not be necessary that he extends himself downwards and lies on the ground; however, if he dislocates his shoulder towards the outside, we must place him as before over two planks so that both arms can reach out to support and the extensive ligaments are stretched according to what we said previously.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	 It is necessary that a compression should also be applied at the place from where he will receive the joint and after the reduction has been completed according to what is necessary.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 "Thou art not hidden from the sign of his redemption; and if you stretch out two limbs to him, he will seize with both hands his breast (the crus) and extend it without any excuse: then thou knowest that now has been given a limb as is necessary; then you bind up the two thighs together, lay on an implement, and tighten with rope, namely, stretched so that there may not be moved by any part of him towards one side or the other. And he will remain quiet in three days or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	 "Then you loosen the ligature and implement, and compare the legs together; then if you see that they are equal in their standing, then you know that the dislocation has already been fixed; so therefore the limb is now straight for walking.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	 "And if you see any softening of the leg; then remove it and the implement, and tighten it according to your first ligature; and give it also quiet in three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	 "Then you loosen that leg, make him rest a little while for walking over some time, until he is well-adjusted.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	 "Of dislocations of the thigh.
Caput XXXIII.	 "Thigh 33.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	 The thigh can be dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	 It can be dislocated externally, internally, and downwardly or downwards towards the back.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	 "And it is not dislocated forwards.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	 The sign of its dislocation is that the limb applies its leg towards itself in pain and discomfort.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	 "If it does not stay together with the thigh; then you know that the thigh has been dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	 "The restoration of all the modes for its dislocation is that you make him rest the straight limb; so that now it can extend if it is able to the leg on top, and keep your back against his face; and put the foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	 "Then you hold it with your hands to the thigh on top of him; and place them straight over his thigh between your fingers.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	 In order to apply with your hand two lateral surfaces of his knee joint when he is in a state of strength
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	 And another assistant extends the foot towards him until it reaches its place (i.e., his knee).
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	 The sign of relief was put on so that he could grasp the thigh while lying down without exertion.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	 He then grasps him and holds tight to the thigh.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 And at that time (i.e., when he has grasped it) he will hold onto it with both hands for 2 or 4 days depending on how long his hand stays attached to the thigh.
Deinde solue ea.	 And then he releases him.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	 Unless he is too weak and cannot walk around for a certain number of days until he recovers.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	 If however you refuse to release him and insist on trying to move his body again with the aid of strong assistants who support his ankles while they are being described (presumably as part of a medical treatment) until he recovers.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	 The cure for dislocated ankles
Caput XXXIIII.	 The 14th Chapter
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	 The ankle can be pulled away from its normal position or dislocated by force at right angles to itself.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	 The dislocation is either towards the inside of his leg or towards the outside
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	 The sign of dislocation was put on so that you can inflate and position his ankle so it is dislocated in such a way as to heal faster.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	 The cure for dislocation is easy and quick: just have assistants hold his ankle while it is being pulled towards the right position with ease using their hands so that once it has been moved to its place he will be held on until he recovers.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	 When dislocation occurs towards the inside of his leg however you must ensure that he is not made to lie on an uneven surface and assistants hold him while being held gently by strong men from behind who support his feet so they are at right angles with each other in the middle of it until he recovers.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	 You should then hold his right foot towards its top part and with your left hand from below the lower part of his feet until you reach each ankle separately.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	 And then pull it towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	 "On both sides.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	 "Extend on the left and pull towards the belly with the right foot, without effort (or: without strain).
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	 "Do it twice as we did before.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	 "Pull the belly towards the heel on the third time, and you will draw the rope.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	 "If so returned on the first time (that is, if you pulled him towards the heel in one motion), or twice as we did before and both feet equally equaled, then this was a good thing; but if not, do it again over his body: for he himself has done it.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	 "If you are not allowed to pull him with him as we did before, then let go of the rope while standing on your back and place a firm peg in the ground at one side so that he falls between his legs: and you will have pulled the sheet over it.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	 "Then receive the foot of him as his minister; after that, let your other minister extend it, either with your hands or with a rope tied above the leg.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	 "Then let every minister stretch against his own comparison (that is, the ministers of both feet should extend equally), so that the peg may remain between two legs holding him up without drawing his body towards the lower side.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	 "Then let your other minister hold tight to the good foot towards the lower side.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	 "The dislocation was accompanied by fatigue.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	 "Then declare the health of his restoration to you; and fasten tightly with a peg and a rope, and tie it firmly with a strong cord, and bind the leg with its band towards the heel.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	 "And you must make sure that when you pull or push from the posterior part of his heels above, they do not carry the cord over them, and let go of them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 "Then release him in two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	 "If the band becomes slack, tie him up again; and then release him on the third or fourth day, or after forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	 "If a man is able to walk before reaching that space without fear of dislocation occurring and dissolution following from it, security does not exist; otherwise he must prepare for its destruction.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	 "If you deliver him a cold cup of water at that moment (i.e., during the process), then it is necessary for you to administer his medication there, which precedes our narration elsewhere due to care and anointing; otherwise remove the result.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	 "Regarding the dislocation of a finger or hand, cure [the cause].
Caput XXXV.	 "Head number 35.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	 "It is necessary for it to be made equal when dislocated with slight extension and without effort; however, that thing itself isn't difficult at all, but easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	 "If the dislocation occurs due to some knots of the forearm's finger(s), then it is necessary for him to support his foot on the ground or table in such a way that it is as if walking; and he remains like this until healed.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	 "Afterwards you remain there [i.e., supporting his foot on the ground or table], and place your hand upon that from which he is coming.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	 "And strike it with his foot along with vigor until it is redressed; and you should then strike him again to make him equal once more, and he will not appear to be superior.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	 "And place your foot beneath his feet as if it can support the entire foot; there are two hands for that purpose.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	 "And then stretch him with a decent cord over three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	 "Then remove him and make him rest from all movement for several days until he is stretched and securely reduced.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	 "Regarding the species of dislocations along with fractures.
Caput XXXVI.	 "Head number 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	 "When something happens to him and you cure his illness and restoration of it, many times there is death; and for that reason it is not necessary that he should become superior in the care of him as a result, which I have said earlier unless someone who is prudent with long use in the art of medicine, compassionate, pious, slow, without fearlessness, or extravagant. And to be used by doctors who administer cold bandages.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	 "Unless you wish for good health and salvation from damnation with gentleness and humility, there is no hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	 Therefore, reduce its severity at the very beginning of things before it can cause coldness to others.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	 If therefore you reduce the limb according to our wishes, then immediately administer a treatment that will make it healthy again; and care for wounds with its assistance in drying out through ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	 If the dislocation occurs with a fracture and they are separated by separating pains, then you must cure their wounds as we instructed earlier through it what preceded them from its simple remedies.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	 And so, according to your virtue and trust me when you come into the house of fear; according to what I have taught you before.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	 That is better for you with your Creator and remaining to glory, and more food for your body among those of yours at that time.
